9 hours ago, max_creative said:

Just looked back and still don't get it. 

 

OK, what we were talking about, in a nutshell, is a battle where a handful of little American destroyers and carrier escorts stood up against a Japanese fleet many times bigger..... way bigger.  The American fleet was outgunned, out sized, out numbered.... but they stood their ground.

One thing a Destroyer had back then that larger cruisers and battleships didn't is torpedoes.  Like a more modern PT boat.  And these crazy destroyer captains, knowing they had no other choice, ordered their ships right down the Japanese fleets throat so they could get close enough to launch the torpedoes, even though it was suicide.

While this was happening, what few planes the Americans had began harassing the big Japanese ships, again, with little chance of success.... but they went.

The Americans got pounded, bad.  But they kept at it, and did some really serious damage to the bigger Japanese ships.... so much that the Japanese admiral in charge thought he was facing a much larger fleet, and ended up turning and heading back home!

This little handful of ships turned back a fleet ten times bigger than it was.

 

Now, how this relates to the story... or fan-fiction stories in general.  Some of the captains, especially the one in the lead destroyer, were crazy.  But in a way his crew loved, and respected.  So much they were willing to die for him, if ordered.  This is a special kind of crazy, a Captain Kirk kind of crazy.  I've seen it, and it's real.  It makes a captain seem larger than life, almost invincible... and sometimes it does really seem the crazier they are, the more the people they command love them for it.

And if someone, myself or anyone else, is writing about a ships captain, this is something they should understand and consider when giving the character a personality.

Chapter 38
     The Pit of the Kraken  

 

It was late, the shadows were growing long, and Gene Kerman stood alone atop the vehicle assembly building, watching the sun set behind the western mountains

How often in the last few weeks had he escaped up here to find a moments peace he could not count. Too often, perhaps. But it was the only place he knew of to get away... and he used to love coming up here with... with... her.

And now he sought a moments peace before the big event. He knew the press had already gathered below his feet. Ahhhh, the press. How he had come to hate facing them and their endless questions. And tonight... tonight, they would be relentless. Tonight history would be made.Tonight, at long last, the Diamondback was making her final burn into orbit high over Duna.

Duna.... he had come to both love and hate the word..... and the planet. They had huge successes with the arrival of the fleet of robotic parts ships, and the assembly of their new station over Duna, as well as a mining colony on Ike. But what should have been their crowning achievement had turned into an endless headache, all because of the twins, Gem and Theo, and their little "prank".

Luckily the Diamondback crew seemed to get a handle on them, more or less, and the flight to Duna went without too many problems.... again, more or less. There was one incident, the first, last, and only time the twins were allowed in the cockpit together. Within minutes of strapping themselves in, Theo had bet Gem she couldn't roll the mighty ship as fast as a doodlebug, a bet she absolutely couldn't refuse.... and didn't.

Thankfully Jeb was able to stop the ship before any serious damage was done, and once Bill had stopped heaving into a space-sickness bag, he went out and replaced the solar panel they had managed to rip free.

After the panel had been repaired, the twins were never allowed up front again, and things managed to go fairly smoothly until the reached Duna's SOI. 

But back at home things were anything but smooth for Gene. Despite the PR departments best efforts, there had still been a rash of runaway children showing up at KASA's front gate, their angry parents not far behind. Then the near insurgency amongst his own cadet corps by those that felt cheated and slighted at the children being chosen before them. That was something Gene had to quell as well, before they lost half their experienced cadets.

And the twins parents, Jandolin and Harfield.... Harfield had always been the strong one, and seemed to be taking the situation fairly well. But Jandolin, the twins mother... she was a wreck, and Gene worried the stress was seriously splitting her in two. On one side there was Jandolin the scientist, who knew and understood that the laws of physics just couldn't not be broken, and no matter how she felt about it, she would have to be patient and wait two more years to see her children.

One the other side, Jandolin the mother didn't care. She felt it was all a load of kraken crap, and wanted them home now.

It was getting late, and Gene knew he would be summoned to the briefing room soon, but he stayed to the last possible moment and continued to think of his people. Besides Jandolin and Harfield and the twins, there was the issue of Piper, the commander of Emiko Station..... if there was an issue. He really wasn't sure. All knew he know was after Piper's collapse on the Mun, she had changed... somehow. It was hard for him to pin down.... just something about her was different. It was as if she had become even harder than she already was.... and this hardness was now somehow sharpened.... and this also worried him. But he knew she spent most of her off time talking with her best friend Kerenna, and this seemed to help.

Kerenna.... Kerenna..... Gene tried so very hard not to think about her. The first few days after she had left he was too busy to think about much of anything. But once things had died down to the usual routine, he realized he missed his friend... a lot. Every time he thought of her big beautiful buggly eyes, her cute emerald dimples, her gorgeous stumpy legs... and mostly her adorable laugh... it felt as if a piece of his heart was missing, and he wasn't sure how to handle it. He couldn't ever imagine someone as beautiful as his emerald cheeked Kerenna ever loving him, but deep inside, he couldn't lie to himself anymore.

He truly did love her.

Behind him a voice broke the silence. "Sir, they're ready..."

 

*          *          *

 

High about Duna Kerenna Kerman sat in the cockpit of the Diamondback and counted down, "Three, two, one... burn." And with a savage grin her might she pushed the throttle of the Diamondback to full.

Next to Kerenna, Gem, acting as co-pilot, read the display and calmly announced, "All systems looking good, temperatures normal, estimated burn time 90 seconds... mark."

"Mark," Kerenna replied, eyes never leaving her instrument panel. And for the next 90 seconds, everyone held their breath and hoped the fuel calculations had been correct. 

Finally the agonizing silence was broken my Gem's calm voice, "...and.... 5... 4... 3... 2.... throttle down." 

Kerenna pulled back on the throttle, checked her instruments, and to everyone's relief announced, "Engines all reading in the green, fuel levels higher than estimated.... KASA, we are in orbit over Duna!"

Once the cheering and celebrating died down, the crew sat back, relaxed, and waited on a new Duna raptor, already in orbit, and heading out to rendezvous with Diamondback and take the crew on their last leg to the awaiting Duna Station.

This newest raptor was the most modern yet, and had the added feature of a small ore drill and fuel processor, making it capable of refueling itself on Ike and much more independent than previous raptors. But it came at the sacrifice by only seating five, so it was decided Jeb and Bob would remain behind for now to oversee the Diamondback's refueling, and join up with the rest later.

Aboard the Duna Raptor, Val took the helm, targeted Duna Station, and plotted an intercept course, while everyone in back enjoyed the view of Duna growing larger and larger in the side windows.

But as much in awe as they were of the great red planet, the real gasps came when Duna Station loomed into view, and the crew saw their temporary new home up close for the first time.

The station was beautiful, and huge, even larger than Emiko Tower, but similar in design. This was a masterpiece, and even though Val and the others had seen the blueprints, the real thing was still staggering. 

Once docked, the Raptor was topped off and the crew prepared to separate again. 

This time Val and Bill would be remaining onboard and begin the final phases of bringing the massive station online while Kerenna and the twins proceeded to Ike and begin bringing the colony base online, and exploring the surrounding region. It had been planned originally for Kerenna herself to proceed to Ike, but after much deliberation it was decided the twins should accompany her for a couple reasons. 

First, the area really did need exploring, and having the twins take up the responsibility could greatly accelerate this process. 

Second, the simple fact was there was no better doodlebug pilot in the fleet than Gem, and with the new doodlebug-II's onboard science equipment, they should be able to gather a lot of very important data other pilots might not be able to acquire.

Third, it was hoped letting them lose on the surface with something to do might help keep the twins occupied and out of too much trouble.

And so Kerenna took the Raptor onto mysterious Ike, and was soon plotting the ships final decent and landing.

But as they made their final pass, Theo called out, "What.... what is that? Aunty-K, roll 60 degrees to starboard. What is that near the landing zone?"

As the ship rolled, the small strange area came into better view... and appeared to be a weird dark patch of... something dark.... something black, maybe a kilometer north of the colony. And as they came in for their landing, it just seemed to get darker, blacker, and more mysterious. It was like a patch of deepest blackness, so dark it was hard to distinguish if it was a mark on the surface, or some vast pit. And the readings coming in were like nothing Kerenna or the rest had ever seen... it was almost as if something down there did, but also did not, exist, depending on which reading you looked at. It was very different than anything they had encountered to this point, but didn't seem threatening in any real way. 

It was just... weird.

As Kerenna began her final roll into landing position, dr. von Kerman's voice came over her intercom speaker.

"Mission control to Duna Raptor, we are monitoring your situation. Be advised, our satellite imaging does not... repeat, does NOT show this dark area in previous passes. Proceed with caution"

"Understood," Kerenna answered, looking down at her panel. The reading were still erratic, to say the least, and she prayed her navigation didn't go out on her until they were firmly on the ground.

In the back, Gem reached over and poked Theo with her elbow and said, "Betcha there's a Kraken living down there."

Theo poked her back. "No way... Kraken's aren't real."

Gem laughed and looked back out the window, "Sure they are... betcha there's one living in that pit right now. That's a Kraken pit for sure..."

Up front Kerenna called back, "Would you two stop until we land, please?"

And such was their curiosity with the weird black area, they actually did stop and behave. But then, with less than a kilometer to go, Gem called out called out calmly bit firmly, "Aunty-K, I need you to roll 70 degrees to starboard and translate 20 more meters north, please."

"Confirmed," Kerenna acknowledged, and then asked, "What's the problem, dear?"

"Oh, no problem now, but we were about to crash into a giant boulder floating next to the base."

"What?" Kerenna gasped, unable to see from her position in the cockpit, "Floating, are you sure?"

"Yes, ma'am, definitely... I can tell from it's shadow.  And Aunty-K... it's really, really huge. Be careful and maintain this course... wait, no, translate 10 more meters north... OK, that's better. We should clear it fine now"

And with Gem acting as a second pair of eyes, they did land safely along side the colony... and the huge floating rock that hovered next to it.

Gem hadn't misspoke, the floating rock was huge, nearly as tall as the Raptor itself, and clearly hovering more than a meter from the surface. Inside the ship, Kerenna told the twins to stay put, geared up and climbed down to the surface, and switched her radio over to her private Emiko Station frequency.

"Piper, this is Kere.... are you reading?"

After a few seconds delay Piper Kerman replied, "Yes, dear, I'm reading. What is your situation? Are you and the children alright?"

"Yes, dear, we're fine. Mission has been a complete success so far. But look, we've encountered something odd. Two something's, actually.The first I'm not even sure how to put into words. But the second..."

"Yes?"

"Piper, we've encountered a floating boulder, right along side the base... and it's.. it's massive! As tall as the colony base, maybe taller. How should I proceed?"

Piper was quiet for a second, the replied, "Of course..... why is this not unexpected??? Kere, listen, do not, I repeat, do not touch or disturb it in any way. And do not let the children too close, either. And under no circumstances let either of them touch it.. this is vital, understood? Do not touch it!"

Kerenna looked up at the massive floating rocked and whispered, "Oh, don't worry, dear.... I'm not getting any closer to that thing than I am now."

Quietly she stood and watched the mighty rock.... but then looking up, Kerenna realized that the sun was close to setting, and the Ike nights were notorious long. So she hurried the twins into the colony base with the promise they could examine the floating rock from the safety of the science lab to their hearts content in the morning.

Once the children were secure inside, Kerenna climbed onto the top of the colony command copula and gazed out at the weird black patch..... the Kraken Pit, as Gem had named it... in wonder and curiosity.

And as the sun set over the western Ike mountains, she whispered softly to herself, "Gene... my love.... I wish you were to here with me to see this..."

 

 

The Saga of Emiko Station is far, far from over.....
